stem: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. His wife reports that he was fine this morning but started exhibiting these symptoms about an hour ago. His vital signs are: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 95% on room air. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Identify the actions the nurse should take.

itemContext.sbar: S: John Smith, 68-year-old male, arrived at 14:30 with acute right-sided weakness and slurred speech, onset approximately one hour prior. Wife reports he was well this morning. B: History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No known allergies. A: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 95% on room air. Neurological assessment reveals right-sided facial droop and decreased motor strength in the right arm and leg. GCS score is 14. R: STAT CT scan of the head is ordered to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. Neurology consult requested. Prepare for possible thrombolytic therapy if CT negative for hemorrhage. Monitor neurological status closely.

rationale.correct:
The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of an acute stroke, necessitating immediate intervention to minimize potential brain damage. Notifying the healthcare provider promptly ensures timely medical evaluation and treatment. Preparing for thrombolytic therapy is crucial if the CT scan rules out hemorrhage, as it can dissolve the clot and restore blood flow. Continuous neurological monitoring allows for early detection of any deterioration or improvement in the patient's condition. Elevating the head of the bed to 30 degrees helps reduce intracranial pressure. Obtaining a STAT CT scan is essential to differentiate between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke, guiding subsequent treatment decisions.

clinicalPearl: "Time is brain" underscores the importance of rapid assessment and intervention in stroke management to improve patient outcomes.
questionTrap: Students might prioritize interventions that are part of routine care but not the most critical in the acute phase of stroke management.
mnemonic: Use the mnemonic "FAST" (Face, Arms, Speech, Time) to quickly assess for stroke symptoms.
rationale.incorrect: Administering oral antihypertensive medication without knowing the type of stroke can be harmful. Providing food or fluids can lead to aspiration if the patient has impaired swallowing. Delaying notification of the healthcare provider or failing to monitor neurological status can result in irreversible brain damage.
